content:
This standard outlines JYSK's general requirements for assembly instructions and manuals for mattresses, indoor and outdoor furniture. It aims to provide clear expectations for all JYSK products in these categories, including guidelines on creating informative warnings, assembly steps, and user and maintenance instructions.

Throughout this document, the terms below will be used as follows:

• An Assembly Instruction (AI) is meant for assembling a product.

• A manual will refer to a manual, meant for using a product, e.g. massage function in a massage chair, solar lamp.

• The term Downloads refer to the download area found on the left panel inside Supplier Guideline, here you can find text, templates, pictograms and graphic for inspiration and use, when building AIs and manuals.

An instruction must consist of a Front page and Warning section following the JYSK guidelines and the category standard for the product type.

This is the general information, sketches, and layouts for how JYSK wants manuals build. JYSK defines manuals into consisting of 4 different instructions as follows:

• Assembly instruction (AI).

• Every product requiring assembly must have an AI.

• Warnings.

• Contains text essential for product safety, use and assembly.

• Manual

• Required for any products with more than one function, or where the functions are not self-explanatory.

• Maintenance instruction.

• For any product which the supplier assesses must have specific maintenance instructions, or for products for which maintenance instructions are mandatory, e.g. garden furniture.

Which information to be included in the single instruction is determined by the product, and a decision made by the supplier and approved by JYSK C&Q.

In the following chapter 2, there will be a section-by-section review with examples of

the JYSK way to build an AI. Please be aware that depending on product type, not all sections are relevant or should be included. This will be stated in the related section.

It is the supplier's responsibility to keep up to date with the current version of any standard relevant for the product type in the countries where the product is sold, and that the product is labeled with warnings according to these standards.

• The AI must be saved as PDF, and the file name must contain the JYSK name of the product and the JYSK article number.

• AI must be sent to assemblyinstructions@jysk.com. If there are any general questions regarding the design of the AI, please contact assemblyinstructions@jysk.com (write in English) – JYSK does not proof read the instructions, as we can only check layout, print and overall compliance with this standard. It is not possible to evaluate if a product can be assembled by looking at a document, therefore it is the supplier’s responsibility to ensure this.

• Templates for mandatory use for AI is made available as JYSK XXXXX in the Downloads section. Suppliers must use these templates to make JYSK AI have a uniform and recognizable appearance.

• The writing in the AI must be with Font Verdana, no smaller than size 6, and with headlines for warnings in bold, italic writing with CAPITAL letters.

• AI must be printed on white paper min. 70g./m2 and

in if size A4 (21 x 29,7 cm) portrait page layout, on both sides in a good, clear print and stapled in upper left corner. If the manual is made on paper A3 (29,7 x 42 cm) and folded, it is very important that staples are placed exactly where the paper is folded, and the frame is clear from folding and staples.

• For some simple products an instruction in A5 size booklet can be accepted. This must be agreed with JYSK C&Q.

Below are listed key requirements for any AI/manual:

• A4 format

• Portrait page layout – use the JYSK 10020

• Templates

• Font Verdana

• Correct JYSK logo: JYSK 00005

• Relevant warnings

• JYSK prefers the use of pictograms instead of text

• All text must be translated (not Product name)

• All pages must have a frame, which is approx. 10 mm from paper edge

• All pages must be in black/white printing

• All pages must have a page number

• One staple (upper left corner) must keep the pages together

• If printed on A3 and folded use 3 staples in the middle of the fold, avoid that the staples cover any writing or drawing

• All text for warnings must be at least Font size 6 – and always clearly readable

• It is always the suppliers’ responsibility that AI/manuals are correct, handwritten corrections and so forth are not accepted by JYSK

• Saved as a PDF and named with the JYSK name of the product and the JYSK product number

The AI, user instruction and manual must comply with the requirements in JYSK 1009.

All writing must be translated to the number of languages currently used by JYSK, see General Requirements. Some readymade translations for warnings can be found in the Supplier Guideline Downloads section. For product specific warnings, it is the

supplier’s own responsibility to make translations. Avoid using Google Translate and similar tools as they do not offer reliable translations.

As normally JYSK provides translation of some of the most commonly used warnings, these can be found in the Downloads section of JYSK Supplier Guideline. When translations are not available we recommend using Language Wire for translations JYSK 10251.

WEEE information for Electrical and Electronic equipment must be given in accordance with JYSK 4005.

Warnings regarding electric components and toys must follow the current standard for the specific product – be aware that standards can differ in the countries in which JYSK products are sold.

Note: For electric components please read JYSK 4005 and for toys JYSK 2001.

Front page (page 1) see Figure 1.

Figure 1 and 2.1.1 of the AI or user manual must show the product in a clear, detailed 3D sketch.

• It must include the exact outer measurements of the product in millimeters (mm).

• It must be with the JYSK logo, JYSK product name, JYSK Nordic and DBL article number and the applicable Info-tri logo in accordance to JYSK 6101.

• If the product is made from FCS certified wood, it must be shown on the front page too, with the producer’s certificate number.

JYSK 10020 must be used as the template for the front page. This and later mentioned templates can be found in the Supplier Guideline Downloads section.

Page 2 of the AI must show the product in 2D sketches without fronts (doors and drawers). It must show a top view, front view and side view. On the views, the most important and useful dimensions must be shown.

If the product contains a drawer or shoe storage or the like, the internal size of this must be shown also. This is shown best with a 3D drawing see 2.2.

The purpose of this page is to inform customers about the most important measures, e.g., if there is enough space for a small storage box or how big the distance is between two legs on a dining table.

Page 2 is mandatory for the types of furniture for relevant products. Below listed are examples:

• Storage furniture (Sideboards, TV-units, display cabinets, wardrobes, bookshelves, chest of drawers, console tables, bedside tables, shoe racks, other small furniture with storage options etc.).

• Desks

• Dining tables

• Beds

For other furniture types, page 2 is not to be included.

Page 7/48

All manuals for storage furniture must include the important measurement page with the following dimensions:

• External height, length, and depth.

• Width of all shelves.

• Depth of shelves.

• Height between shelves and top plate/bottom plate including the distance the shelves can be moved.

• Distance from floor to bottom plate or bottom rail if the distance is >50 mm.

• Internal size of drawer or shoe storage or the like in 3D drawing.

See example for a storage furniture Figure 3.

Example for a room divider Figure 4.

Page 8/48

All manuals for desks must include the important measurement page with the following dimensions:

• External height, length, and depth.

• Space for seating. Both the width and the height must be shown.

• Height between shelves and top plate/bottom plate including the distance the shelves can be moved.

• Distance from floor to bottom plate or bottom rail if the distance is >50 mm.

• Internal size of drawer in 3D drawing.

See example in Figure 5:

All manuals for dining tables must include the important measurement page with the following dimensions:

• External height, length, and width.

• Space for seating. Both the width and height must be shown.

See example in Figure 6:

All manuals for beds must include the important measurement page with the following dimensions:

• External height (for both head- and foot end), length and width.

• Distance between head- and foot end and between bedsides (size for mattress).

• Distance from floor to upper side of support list.

• Distance from floor to lower side of bedside.

• Distance from side support rail to top of bedside.

• Distance from floor to top of bedside.

See example in Figure 7:

The template Figure 8 to be used for showing important measurements in AI. See JYSK 10020.

The warning section is the next part of the manual and will show mandatory warnings and depending on product type special warnings translated into all JYSK languages see General Requirements.

• The order of the warnings must follow the order of the warnings. I.e. the correct order should be warning 2.3.3, 2.3.12.3.4, 2.3.5 and so on.

• The related pictogram for a warning must be shown with the warning text in manuals, and if necessary, in the related steps as well

• For translated warnings provided by JYSK it is NOT allowed to change any text without approval from JYSK C&Q.

• Pictograms must be used with the warning text. The pictograms must be at least 40 mm.

Watermark is to be used on all warning pages Figure 9. The size should be approximately B: 115 x H: 100 mm

Additional warnings or maintenance instructions must be approved by JYSK C&Q. Warning is available as JYSK 10020.

JYSK has designed below template JYSK 10020 to be used for warnings in AI Figure 10.

This warning must be in all AI Figure 11. Warning is available as JYSK 10022.

Scratching product parts during assembly can cause many claims. Warning to avoid scratching of product parts must be included in all relevant AI. Therefore, must the warning and pictogram Figure 12 against this be included in all AI. Warning is available as JYSK 10026.

This warning text and related pictogram Figure 13 must be in all AI and manuals if the product has anti-topple bracket(s). See requirements for anti-topple brackets in category standard JYSK 1004. Warning is available as JYSK 10021.

Figure 13 - Pictogram to be used together with anti-topple warning text and in related steps in AI

This warning text and related pictogram Figure 14 must be in all AI and manuals if the product is a delicate table. Warning is available as JYSK 10036 See requirements for delicate table in EN 12521.

This warning text and related pictogram Figure 15 must be in all AI and manuals if the product is to be mounted on a wall. Typically, products such as mirrors, coat racks, wall shelves, etc. It should NOT be used for products containing anti-topple bracket(s). Warning is available as JYSK 10032.

This warning text and related pictogram Figure 16 must be in all AI and manuals if the product is a desk chair, and it is tested according to EN 12520. Warning is available as JYSK 10027.

This warning text and related pictogram Figure 17 must be in all AI and manuals if the product is an office and gaming chair, and it is tested according to EN 1335. Warning is available as JYSK 10028.

Figure 17 - Pictogram to be used together with warning texts for office and gaming chairs

This warning text must be in all AI and manuals if the product is a chair, armchair, lounge chair or stool etc. and it is tested according to EN 12520. This warning should not contain any pictogram Figure 18. Warning is available as JYSK 10029.

This warning text must be in all AI and manuals if the product is a sofa or bench, and it is tested according to EN 12520. This warning should not contain any pictogram Figure 19 .

This warning should not contain any pictogram. Warning is available as JYSK 10030.

Figure 19 - Warning - regarding sofas and benches (two or more seaters)

Most products assembled by any kind of screws and likewise, will over time become loose and more unstable, especially for tables and chairs Figure 20. Therefore, it is very important that a warning making customers aware of the importance of re-tightening is included in the AI. This warning should not contain any pictogram.

This warning should not contain any pictogram. Warning is available as JYSK 10025.

All products containing elements made of tempered glass must have a warning regarding the handling of tempered glass Figure 21. This warning should not contain any pictogram. Warning is available as JYSK 10024.

This warning text and related pictogram Figure 22 must be in all AI and manuals if the product is made of wood, veneer, painted MDF/HDF/chipboard, melamine, laminate, PP, Steel etc. Warning is available as JYSK 10023.

This warning text and related pictogram Figure 23 must be in all AI and manuals if the product is covered in PU/bonded leather. Warning is available as JYSK 10034.

This warning text and related pictogram Figure 24 must be in all AI and manuals if the product is covered in genuine leather. Warning is available as JYSK 10031.

Figure 24 - Pictogram to be used together with warning text for products covered in genuine leather

This warning text and related pictogram Figure 25 must be in all AI and manuals if the product is covered in fabric. Warning is available as JYSK 10033.

This warning text and related pictogram Figure 26 must be in all AI and manuals if the product is with oiled surfaces. Warning is available as JYSK 10035.

Figure 26 - Pictogram to be used together with warning text for products with oiled surfaces

This warning text and related pictogram Figure 27 must be in all AI and manuals if the product needs warnings in wind or heavy rain. Warning is available as JYSK 10035.

This warning text must be in all AI and manuals if the product is a cushion box Figure 28. This warning should not contain any pictogram. Warning is available as JYSK 10039.

This warning text must be in all AI and manuals if the product is an outdoor furniture that must comply with EN 581 (must be minimum 5 mm high) Figure 29. This warning should not contain any pictogram. Warning is available as JYSK 10040.

Figure 29 - Mandatory warning - outdoor furniture

Page 19/48

This warning must be in all AI and manuals if the product is an outdoor seating furniture that must comply with EN 581 Figure 30. This warning should not contain any pictogram. Warning is available as JYSK 10045.

This warning text must be in all relevant AI and manuals if the product is an outdoor product Figure 31 - Warning no replacing of energy accumulator. This warning should not contain any pictogram. Warning is available as JYSK 10047.

This warning text must be in all relevant AI and manuals if the product is an outdoor product Figure 32. Warning is available as JYSK 10503.

This warning text must be in all relevant AI and manuals if the product is an outdoor product Figure 33. Warning is available as JYSK 10504.

This warning text must be in all relevant AI and manuals if the product is an outdoor product Figure 34. Warning is available as JYSK 10505.

This warning text must be in all relevant AI and manuals if the product is an outdoor product Figure 35. Warning is available as JYSK 10506.

This warning text must be in all relevant AI and manuals if the product is an outdoor product Figure 36. This warning should not contain any pictogram. Warning is available as JYSK 10507.

Page 22/48

Section 4 starts after the warnings section and consists mainly of pictograms. In this section customers are shown which tools and fittings are needed for assembling the product.

Any tools needed for assembly of the product, and which are NOT included in the fitting box must be shown with a pictogram in the tool area. If a special tool may NOT be used for assembly etc. screw machine, it must be shown in the tool area as well, but with a cross over the pictogram.

Note: Tools which are included in the fitting box e.g. a Hex-key or spanner, must be considered as a fitting and must be shown in the fitting area.

JYSK has developed below JYSK line of tool pictograms for mandatory use Figure 37.

Tool pictograms can be found available in JYSK 10050.

Carpenter’s hammer.

Edition 1 – 2025-05 Compliancequality@JYSK.com

| Unnamed: 0   | Do NOT use screw machine    |
|:-------------|:----------------------------|
| nan          | Drilling machine            |
| nan          | Do NOT use drilling machine |
| nan          | L-shaped 90°                |
| nan          | Measure tape                |
| xy           | Spirit level                |
| nan          | Pencil                      |
| nan          | Ladder                      |

It is allowed for the supplier to use their own pictograms or drawings from CAD software to show the fittings. Pictograms must be clearly understandable and must look exactly like the fittings used for assembling.

For the customer to easily recognize the different fittings, the fittings should be shown in 3D view and in the same angle/direction. Screws must be placed with a visible head, so the customer clearly can see which type of screwdriver is needed for the screw.

The fitting overview is made as a table, with cells 40x40 mm Figure 38. The fitting pictograms must be scaled to fit the cells. For the customer to be able to recognize the fittings, the larger fittings as drawer runners etc., can be shown in 2 cells merged to 1 big cell. But this should only be done when it is absolutely needed. The fitting pictogram must be placed in the center of the cell.

Above the fitting pictogram, the fittings must be named with capital letters starting with A, B, C… (English alphabet) and the number of the fittings included (e.g. Ax42).

Meaning that the letter and number of the fitting must be shown in top of each cell.

Note: We do NOT want any fittings named I or O. The reason for this is, that “I” can be exchanged with a “drawing line” and “O” can be exchanged with a “drilling hole”.

• If there are more than 24 different

fittings, you may continue with AA, AB, AC and so on….

Below the fitting pictogram, the size of each fitting must be shown.

• A dowel or screw size is shown as diameter x length (e.g. Ø8x30 mm)

• A bolt defined by tread x length e.g. (M6x30mm)

• A washer defined by internal diameter / external diameter e.g. (Ø6/Ø20mm)

• Ø is the indicator for diameter

• A corner brace or similar fitting size is shown as length x width x high (e.g. 75x25x15 mm.)

All text for fittings must be font Verdana size 10

If there are two or more types of hinges in the fitting box, the different types must be very easy to tell apart in the AI. The hinge and hinge back plate must be pre-assembled, to avoid assembly mistakes.

For runners, which are shipped as one piece, but needs to be separated during the assembly process, it is very important that it is shown as one piece in the fitting overview. More info about how to show it can be split can be found in the assembly steps section.

If necessary, it is OK to spread fitting overviews over more pages.

Section 7 of the AI shows the assembly steps 1 by 1. All steps must include step number, fittings, and tools to be used and a 3D drawing showing the action to be performed on the individual step. Some steps need a special detailed view or warning to be added as well.

Note: A maximum of two assembly steps on each side is allowed.

It is very important the assembling of a product is done in a logical way. I.e. the assembling steps shall also be shown in a logical way. It is important that the customer shall handle each part as few times as possible, as each handling can result in scratch or damage on corners and edges.

The logical assembling way for a sideboard is normally:

1. Building up the cabinet staring from legs, bottom plate, side panels, top plate incl. anti-topple bracket

2. Assemble and mount the drawers

3. Assemble and mount the doors

4. Fix sideboard to the wall with the anti-topple bracket (in some cases this must be done before mounting the drawers)

5. Add any not fixed shelves

6. Adjust the doors, drawers and level out the sideboard with adjustable feet etc.

The logical way of assembling a complete drawer is normally:

1. Mount the excentric bolts to the drawer front

2. Add the needed dowels and if possible, drawer runners to the drawer sides

3. Mount the drawer sides to the drawer front

4. Add

the drawer bottom and in some cases the drawer bottom support

5. Mount the drawer back

6. Mount the handle

The logical way of assembling a door is normally:

1. Mount any magnetic catches, dust list etc. to the back side of the door

2. Mount the complete hinge

3. Mount the handle

Page 31/48

The top bar on each assembly step must be built up as shown in Figure 45.

The top bar includes step numbers, fittings and tools to be used on the current step.

The top bar consists of:

a. A circle app. Ø20 mm. with the assembly step number inside and written in font Verdana size 36

b. A box where a maximum of 4 different fittings can be shown.

The size of each fitting box is app. 24x24 mm. Above each fitting is shown the fitting letter and quantity to be used on the current step (e.g. E x 14). Below each fitting is shown the fitting dimension (e.g. Ø3,5x20 mm.). All text related to the fitting must be font Verdana size 8.

c. To the right, the tools needed for the current step are shown. Note: JYSK standard tool pictograms must be used for tools.

If a step does not require any use of fittings or tools, the top bar box is not needed and only the step number shall be shown see Figure 45.

Fittings are placed in boxes in left side of top bar. Note: Hex-key or spanner included in the fitting box is to be considered as a fitting.

Tools are placed in right side of top bar.

Page 32/48

The 3D drawings on each assembly step must be done in correct proportions and scaling.

The fittings shown in the top bar should all appear on the 3D drawing as well. It is important that it is clearly shown how and where the fittings should be placed and in which holes to mount it. If the customer can make a mistake when doing this, it is important that the warning triangle, a highlight or a detailed view is inserted. This to make it clearer what the customer should be aware of (see more about detail view in 2.7.4).

The tools from the top bar shall only be shown in the 3D drawing if really needed. Normally it is easy for the customer to understand which tool must be used for each fitting.

Note: Hex-key and spanner included in the fitting box is to be considered as a fitting. It is NOT a tool.

Circle w/part number shall be placed on all parts that have a handling on the current step.

It is very important NOT to show too many parts on each step. It is better to make many simple steps instead of less complicated steps.

If some details are hard to see or understand from the 3D drawing in the assembly steps, a high light can be added. A high light is used to show details in a larger scaling. It is important that the high light shown on the step is drawn in the same angle as on the 3D drawing the high light is scaled from. This is in order not to create unnecessary confusion for the customer.

The use of high lights must be limited and only be used when it is absolutely needed.

When needed on assembly steps, a detailed view must be added.

A detail view is a small instruction that shows some extra information – e.g. a small warning to avoid wrong mounting or how a special fitting works.

If the detailed view is about how a fitting works, it only must be shown on the assembly step where the fitting is used for the first time. Means the same detail view, shall NOT be shown on all steps where this fitting is used.

At JYSK we want a uniform determination of max. load from product to product. Therefore, we have set up the following rules for determination of max. load on AI:

Determination of max. load on horizontal surfaces:

• Top plates: max. 40 kg.

• Shelves: max. 10 kg.

• Bottom plates: max. 20 kg.

• Drawers: Max. 5 kg.

• Dining table- and desktops: max. 40 kg.

• Coffee - and side tabletops: max. 20 kg.

Note: Garden furniture max load must comply with requirements in JYSK 1009.

However, for extra product safety, the maximum load displayed must never be greater than 90 % of the load used during test (0.65 kg/dm2) for a horizontal surface.

• Tv units must, in addition to maximum load, have max width of tv in compliance with EN 14749 se Figure 57.

• AI´s for electrically operated beds and beds with lifting mechanisms must show information about mattress weight (e.g. 55 kg) in compliance with EN 1725 see Figure 58.

See below examples of how-to determinate the max. load:

Top plate with size 1600x450 mm.:

16 dm. * 4,5 dm. * 0,65 kg. * 90% = 42,12 kg. ≈ 40 kg. (40 kg. is the max. load for top plates)

Top plate with size 1250x420 mm.:

12,5 dm. * 4,2 dm. * 0,65 kg. * 90% =30,71 kg. ≈ 30 kg.

Glass shelf with size 770x340 mm.:

7,7 dm. * 3,4 dm. * 0,65 kg. * 90% =15,32 kg. ≈ 10 kg. (10 kg. is the max. load for shelves)

Determination of max. load on hanger- and clothes rails:

• Max load 20 kg. pr. meter. It means a rail which is 80 cm. in length has a max. load of 0,8x20 = 16 kg.

Determination of max. load on coat stands:

• Max load 10 kg. pr. “arm”. If 1 arm has 2 hooks, it is 5 kg. pr. hook.

Assembly instructions and manuals

This standard outlines JYSK's general requirements for assembly instructions and manuals for mattresses, indoor and outdoor furniture. It aims to provide clear expectations for all JYSK products in these categories, including guidelines on creating informative warnings, assembly steps, and user and maintenance instructions.
Section Changes All Update to new format. Rewording and cleaning up. New figures and updated examples.

1 Information for reading this document
Throughout this document, the terms below will be used as follows:
• An Assembly Instruction (AI) is meant for assembling a product.
• A manual will refer to a manual, meant for using a product, e.g. massage function in a massage chair, solar lamp.

• The term Downloads refer to the download area found on the left panel inside Supplier Guideline, here you can find text, templates, pictograms and graphic for inspiration and use, when building AIs and manuals.
1.1 Building the assembly instruction (AI)
An instruction must consist of a Front page and Warning section following the JYSK guidelines and the category standard for the product type.
This is the general information, sketches, and layouts for how JYSK wants manuals build. JYSK defines manuals into consisting of 4 different instructions as follows:
• Assembly instruction (AI).
• Every product requiring assembly must have an AI.
• Contains text essential for product safety, use and assembly.
• Required for any products with more than one function, or where the functions are not self-explanatory.
• For any product which the supplier assesses must have specific maintenance instructions, or for products for which maintenance instructions are mandatory, e.g. garden furniture.
Which information to be included in the single instruction is determined by the product, and a decision made by the supplier and approved by JYSK C&Q.

In the following chapter 2, there will be a section-by-section review with examples of the JYSK way to build an AI. Please be aware that depending on product type, not all sections are relevant or should be included. This will be stated in the related section.

It is the supplier's responsibility to keep up to date with the current version of any standard relevant for the product type in the countries where the product is sold, and that the product is labeled with warnings according to these standards.
• The AI must be saved as PDF, and the file name must contain the JYSK name of the product and the JYSK article number.

• AI must be sent to assemblyinstructions@jysk.com. If there are any general questions regarding the design of the AI, please contact assemblyinstructions@jysk.com (write in English) – JYSK does not proof read the instructions, as we can only check layout, print and overall compliance with this standard. It is not possible to evaluate if a product can be assembled by looking at a document, therefore it is the supplier’s responsibility to ensure this.
• Templates for mandatory use for AI is made available as JYSK XXXXX in the Downloads section. Suppliers must use these templates to make JYSK AI have a uniform and recognizable appearance.
• The writing in the AI must be with Font Verdana, no smaller than size 6, and with headlines for warnings in bold, italic writing with CAPITAL letters.

• AI must be printed on white paper min. 70g./m2 and in if size A4 (21 x 29,7 cm) portrait page layout, on both sides in a good, clear print and stapled in upper left corner. If the manual is made on paper A3 (29,7 x 42 cm) and folded, it is very important that staples are placed exactly where the paper is folded, and the frame is clear from folding and staples.
• For some simple products an instruction in A5 size booklet can be accepted. This must be agreed with JYSK C&Q.
Edition 1 – 2025-05 Compliancequality@JYSK.com
Below are listed key requirements for any AI/manual:
• Portrait page layout – use the JYSK 10020
• Correct JYSK logo: JYSK 00005
• JYSK prefers the use of pictograms instead of text
• All text must be translated (not Product name)
• All pages must have a frame, which is approx. 10 mm from paper edge
• All pages must be in black/white printing
• All pages must have a page number
• One staple (upper left corner) must keep the pages together
• If printed on A3 and folded use 3 staples in the middle of the fold, avoid that the staples cover any writing or drawing
• All text for warnings must be at least Font size 6 – and always clearly readable
• It is always the suppliers’ responsibility that AI/manuals are correct, handwritten corrections and so forth are not accepted by JYSK
• Saved as a PDF and named with the JYSK name of the product and the JYSK product number
1.2 Requirements for AI, user instruction and manuals for garden furniture
The AI, user instruction and manual must comply with the requirements in JYSK 1009.

All writing must be translated to the number of languages currently used by JYSK, see General Requirements. Some readymade translations for warnings can be found in the Supplier Guideline Downloads section. For product specific warnings, it is the supplier’s own responsibility to make translations. Avoid using Google Translate and similar tools as they do not offer reliable translations.
1.3.1 Translating warnings for AI and manuals

As normally JYSK provides translation of some of the most commonly used warnings, these can be found in the Downloads section of JYSK Supplier Guideline. When translations are not available we recommend using Language Wire for translations JYSK 10251.
WEEE information for Electrical and Electronic equipment must be given in accordance with JYSK 4005.
1.5 Warning regarding toys and electrical components
Warnings regarding electric components and toys must follow the current standard for the specific product – be aware that standards can differ in the countries in which JYSK products are sold.
Note: For electric components please read JYSK 4005 and for toys JYSK 2001.

2.3 Section 3, warnings
The warning section is the next part of the manual and will show mandatory warnings and depending on product type special warnings translated into all JYSK languages see General Requirements.
• The order of the warnings must follow the order of the warnings. I.e. the correct order should be warning 2.3.3, 2.3.12.3.4, 2.3.5 and so on.

2.4 Section 4, tools and fittings
Section 4 starts after the warnings section and consists mainly of pictograms. In this section customers are shown which tools and fittings are needed for assembling the product.
2.4.1 Tools in AI

Any tools needed for assembly of the product, and which are NOT included in the fitting box must be shown with a pictogram in the tool area. If a special tool may NOT be used for assembly etc. screw machine, it must be shown in the tool area as well, but with a cross over the pictogram.
Note: Tools which are included in the fitting box e.g. a Hex-key or spanner, must be considered as a fitting and must be shown in the fitting area.

2.4.2 Fittings in AI

It is allowed for the supplier to use their own pictograms or drawings from CAD software to show the fittings. Pictograms must be clearly understandable and must look exactly like the fittings used for assembling.

For the customer to easily recognize the different fittings, the fittings should be shown in 3D view and in the same angle/direction. Screws must be placed with a visible head, so the customer clearly can see which type of screwdriver is needed for the screw.

The fitting overview is made as a table, with cells 40x40 mm Figure 38. The fitting pictograms must be scaled to fit the cells. For the customer to be able to recognize the fittings, the larger fittings as drawer runners etc., can be shown in 2 cells merged to 1 big cell. But this should only be done when it is absolutely needed. The fitting pictogram must be placed in the center of the cell.
Above the fitting pictogram, the fittings must be named with capital letters starting with A, B, C… (English alphabet) and the number of the fittings included (e.g. Ax42).
Meaning that the letter and number of the fitting must be shown in top of each cell.
Note: We do NOT want any fittings named I or O. The reason for this is, that “I” can be exchanged with a “drawing line” and “O” can be exchanged with a “drilling hole”.
• If there are more than 24 different fittings, you may continue with AA, AB, AC and so on….
Below the fitting pictogram, the size of each fitting must be shown.
• A dowel or screw size is shown as diameter x length (e.g. Ø8x30 mm)
• A bolt defined by tread x length e.g. (M6x30mm)
• A washer defined by internal diameter / external diameter e.g. (Ø6/Ø20mm)
• Ø is the indicator for diameter
• A corner brace or similar fitting size is shown as length x width x high (e.g. 75x25x15 mm.)
All text for fittings must be font Verdana size 10

If there are two or more types of hinges in the fitting box, the different types must be very easy to tell apart in the AI. The hinge and hinge back plate must be pre-assembled, to avoid assembly mistakes.

For runners, which are shipped as one piece, but needs to be separated during the assembly process, it is very important that it is shown as one piece in the fitting overview. More info about how to show it can be split can be found in the assembly steps section.
If necessary, it is OK to spread fitting overviews over more pages.

2.7 Section 7, assembly steps

Section 7 of the AI shows the assembly steps 1 by 1. All steps must include step number, fittings, and tools to be used and a 3D drawing showing the action to be performed on the individual step. Some steps need a special detailed view or warning to be added as well.
Note: A maximum of two assembly steps on each side is allowed.

It is very important the assembling of a product is done in a logical way. I.e. the assembling steps shall also be shown in a logical way. It is important that the customer shall handle each part as few times as possible, as each handling can result in scratch or damage on corners and edges.
The logical assembling way for a sideboard is normally:
1. Building up the cabinet staring from legs, bottom plate, side panels, top plate incl. anti-topple bracket
2. Assemble and mount the drawers
3. Assemble and mount the doors
4. Fix sideboard to the wall with the anti-topple bracket (in some cases this must be done before mounting the drawers)
5. Add any not fixed shelves
6. Adjust the doors, drawers and level out the sideboard with adjustable feet etc.
The logical way of assembling a complete drawer is normally:
1. Mount the excentric bolts to the drawer front
2. Add the needed dowels and if possible, drawer runners to the drawer sides
3. Mount the drawer sides to the drawer front
4. Add the drawer bottom and in some cases the drawer bottom support
5. Mount the drawer back
6. Mount the handle
The logical way of assembling a door is normally:
1. Mount any magnetic catches, dust list etc. to the back side of the door
2. Mount the complete hinge
3. Mount the handle

2.7.1 Top bar on assembling steps
The top bar on each assembly step must be built up as shown in Figure 45.
The top bar includes step numbers, fittings and tools to be used on the current step.
The top bar consists of:
a. A circle app. Ø20 mm. with the assembly step number inside and written in font Verdana size 36
b. A box where a maximum of 4 different fittings can be shown.

The size of each fitting box is app. 24x24 mm. Above each fitting is shown the fitting letter and quantity to be used on the current step (e.g. E x 14). Below each fitting is shown the fitting dimension (e.g. Ø3,5x20 mm.). All text related to the fitting must be font Verdana size 8.
c. To the right, the tools needed for the current step are shown. Note: JYSK standard tool pictograms must be used for tools.
If a step does not require any use of fittings or tools, the top bar box is not needed and only the step number shall be shown see Figure 45.
Fittings are placed in boxes in left side of top bar. Note: Hex-key or spanner included in the fitting box is to be considered as a fitting.
Tools are placed in right side of top bar.

2.7.2 3D drawings on assembly steps
The 3D drawings on each assembly step must be done in correct proportions and scaling.

The fittings shown in the top bar should all appear on the 3D drawing as well. It is important that it is clearly shown how and where the fittings should be placed and in which holes to mount it. If the customer can make a mistake when doing this, it is important that the warning triangle, a highlight or a detailed view is inserted. This to make it clearer what the customer should be aware of (see more about detail view in 2.7.4).
The tools from the top bar shall only be shown in the 3D drawing if really needed. Normally it is easy for the customer to understand which tool must be used for each fitting.
Note: Hex-key and spanner included in the fitting box is to be considered as a fitting. It is NOT a tool.
Circle w/part number shall be placed on all parts that have a handling on the current step.
It is very important NOT to show too many parts on each step. It is better to make many simple steps instead of less complicated steps.

2.7.3 High lights on assembly steps

If some details are hard to see or understand from the 3D drawing in the assembly steps, a high light can be added. A high light is used to show details in a larger scaling. It is important that the high light shown on the step is drawn in the same angle as on the 3D drawing the high light is scaled from. This is in order not to create unnecessary confusion for the customer.
The use of high lights must be limited and only be used when it is absolutely needed.

2.7.4 Detail views on assembly steps
When needed on assembly steps, a detailed view must be added.
A detail view is a small instruction that shows some extra information – e.g. a small warning to avoid wrong mounting or how a special fitting works.

If the detailed view is about how a fitting works, it only must be shown on the assembly step where the fitting is used for the first time. Means the same detail view, shall NOT be shown on all steps where this fitting is used.

2.8 Section 8, maximum load and last page
Section 8 of the AI is the page where the maximum load is shown.
Last page is the final back side of the AI
2.8.1 Maximum load on horizontal surfaces
The pictograms to be used for showing maximum loads on horizontal surfaces and cloth rails are shown in examples below:

Pictogram: Explanation: Maximum load for the part, shown as an equally distributed load. The symbol for maximum load must be followed by the exact weight load for the part shown in kilos (kg). • For parts with the same weight load, the two symbols only needs to be shown once and then linked with reference lines to parts. • Different loads needs to be shown individually, linked with reference lines to the part. • Maximum load must be shown on each horizontal surface in storage furniture (shelves, drawers, top and bottom). • Maximum load must be shown on hanger rails and clothes rails, (still a sticker must be added on the cloth rail itself). • Maximum load must be shown on all tables (dining tables, coffee tables, console tables, desks and so). • Maximum load is NOT allowed to be shown on any seating products (chairs, armchairs, office chairs, pouffes, stools, sofas and so). • Maximum load is NOT allowed to be shown on any kind of bed (sofa beds, day beds, bed frames, mattresses and so on). • Maximum load is NOT allowed to be shown on products which are wall mounted (wall shelves, coat racks, floating shelves, picture ledges and so).
Figure 56 - Examples for maximum load pictogram
2.8.2 General rules for calculation of maximum load
At JYSK we want a uniform determination of max. load from product to product. Therefore, we have set up the following rules for determination of max. load on AI:
Determination of max. load on horizontal surfaces:
• Top plates: max. 40 kg.
• Shelves: max. 10 kg.
• Bottom plates: max. 20 kg.
• Drawers: Max. 5 kg.
• Dining table- and desktops: max. 40 kg.
• Coffee - and side tabletops: max. 20 kg.
Note: Garden furniture max load must comply with requirements in JYSK 1009.
However, for extra product safety, the maximum load displayed must never be greater than 90 % of the load used during test (0.65 kg/dm2) for a horizontal surface.
Edition 1 – 2025-05 Compliancequality@JYSK.com
• Tv units must, in addition to maximum load, have max width of tv in compliance with EN 14749 se Figure 57.
Figure 57 - Example of max width of TV
• AI´s for electrically operated beds and beds with lifting mechanisms must show information about mattress weight (e.g. 55 kg) in compliance with EN 1725 see Figure 58.
Figure 58 - Example of max mattress weight on bed with lifting mechanism
Edition 1 – 2025-05 Compliancequality@JYSK.com
See below examples of how-to determinate the max. load:
Top plate with size 1600x450 mm.:
16 dm. * 4,5 dm. * 0,65 kg. * 90% = 42,12 kg. ≈ 40 kg. (40 kg. is the max. load for top plates)
Top plate with size 1250x420 mm.:
Glass shelf with size 770x340 mm.:
7,7 dm. * 3,4 dm. * 0,65 kg. * 90% =15,32 kg. ≈ 10 kg. (10 kg. is the max. load for shelves)
Determination of max. load on hanger- and clothes rails:
• Max load 20 kg. pr. meter. It means a rail which is 80 cm. in length has a max. load of 0,8x20 = 16 kg.
Determination of max. load on coat stands:
• Max load 10 kg. pr. “arm”. If 1 arm has 2 hooks, it is 5 kg. pr. hook.

3 User instruction/manual for use

This section is relevant if a specific instruction regarding use of a product must be stated. User instruction is only required if the product has more than one function or if it is not self-explanatory. Chairs, tables, wardrobes, chest of drawers, beds etc. are considered self-explanatory.
If there is electric components in a product e.g. a massage chair, user instructions must be included.
